Award.AwardTitle: Microscopic Theory of Many-Particle Systems from Nuclear Physics to Cold Atoms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award continues an ongoing program to develop fundamental theories of many-particle systems, ranging from nuclei and nuclear matter to cold atoms, with applications to astrophysical and condensed matter systems. A major focus is on understanding new states of matter formed under extreme conditions, especially quark gluon plasmas produced in ultrarelativistic heavy ion collisions. The program applies nuclear theory to neutron stars and supernovae, with the aim of understanding observations and, conversely, using observations to learn the properties of matter. The research on atomic Bose-Einstein and superfluid Fermi systems, a vital facet of the study of unusual states of matter, focusses on atomic states at low temperature, as well as under extreme rotation. This research also makes important interdisciplinary connections between ultracold atomic systems and dense nuclear matter.


The nuclear and atomic systems being studied are very unusual many-particle systems which provide broad intellectual insights. By working across the boundaries between nuclear and atomic physics this program enables the building of bridges and cross-fertilization between the hottest and coldest many-particle systems in the universe. A vital component of this research program is the education of young scientists who, through the broad training they receive and their intimate involvement in the research of the PI's and colleagues, develop the ability to combine nuclear, particle, astro, condensed matter and cold atom physics research on forefront problems. The scientists trained in this program have generally gone on to have significant impact in research at U.S. universities and national laboratories, as well as abroad.

Matter can take on many forms, from familiar gases, liquids, and solids,
to unusual states such as superfluids which flow without friction to superconductors which conduct electricity without resistance.    In recent years, physicists have created several new forms of matter -- the densest hottest matter in the universe called a "quark-gluon plasma," and the coldest matter in the universe, in the form of trapped atomic gases.   The former has been created since the turn of this century at the Brookhaven Relativistic Collider (RHIC) in the U.S., and more recently at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Switzerland.  The latter has been explored in table-top experiments in laboratories originally in the U.S., and now at laboratories around the world.  Research on this Grant has been aimed at expanding our knowledge matter of under extreme conditions.

Important technological applications have the potential to flow eventually from our deeper understanding the properties of such extreme states of matter, particularly when we examine these states from an interdisciplinary perspective. Understanding how groups of particles, from quarks to atoms, behave and act in concert provides deeper insights into the laws governing the microscopic universe and the basic properties of the world we live in.  Research on this Grant continues the building of new bridges between nuclear-particle physics, atomic physics and condensed matter physics.

An important component of the present research program is its interdisciplinary approach to problems of many-particle systems that crosses subfields, bringing to bear experience over the years in a wide spectrum of research in condensed matter, atomic, nuclear, and astrophysics. Our research in one area continues to generate new insights and approaches in other areas, e.g., laboratory superconductivity studies leading to new approaches to superconductivity in quark-gluon plasmas, and nuclei and quark matter studies raising new issues in relativistic many-body theory. Expertise developed for condensed matter and atomic systems has been a significant aspect of the group's study of dense and hot matter.   We mention more salient facets of our research.
